descriptions.content:
Like other nominalizers, ས་ can form nominal clauses as well as relative clauses. This nominalizer relates to the location or the goal of the verbal action. (In other words, the suffix indicates locative adverbials and indirect objects.)

  • འབྲི་ས་ “The place where one writes, or upon which one writes”
  • ཕུལ་ས་ (འབུལ་ས་) “The place where one makes an offering,” “the person to whom one makes an offering”
  • ཞུ་ས་ “The person to whom one speaks,” “the place where one speaks”
  • ཉལ་ས་ “The place where one sleeps”
  • འགྲོ་ས་ “The place toward which one goes,” “the trail”

The verb to which the suffix ས་ is attached appears in the present-future stem form, but it may be used in the context of the past, present, or future:

  • ཞུ་ས་ but not *ཞུས་ས་
  • ཟ་ས་ but not *བཟས་ས་
  • བལྟ་ས་ but not *བལྟས་ས་

Formulations with ས་ are very common in Tibetan, and may sometimes be translated by nouns in European languages.

  • འདིར་བསྡད་ས་(སྡོད་ས་)འདུག་གས། “Is there a room here?”
  • སྣུམ་བླླུག་ས་ག་པར་འདུག “Where’s the gas station?”
  • སྤ་སེ་ཉོ་ས་ཕ་གིར་འདུག “The ticket office is over there.”
  • འདི་ཇ་འཐུང་ས་རེད་པས། “Is that a teashop?” Or, “Is that a teacup?”

In these examples, the four substantives “room,” “gas station,” “ticket office,” and “teacup” would be translated literally as “sitting place,” “gasoline pouring place,” “ticket buying place,” and “tea drinking place.”

The nominalizer ས་ provides no clues about the tense-aspect of the verb, which has to be deduced from the context.
